data.intro:
Four score and seven years ago our fathers brought forth on this continent a new nation, conceived in Liberty, and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal.

Now we are engaged in a great civil war, testing whether that nation or any nation so conceived and so dedicated, can long endure. Rebel spaceships, striking from a hidden base, have won their first victory against the evil Galactic Empire.

During the battle, Rebel spies managed to steal secret plans to the Empire's ultimate weapon, the DEATH STAR, an armored space station with enough power to destroy an entire planet.

Pursued by the Empire's sinister agents, Princess Leia races home aboard her starship, custodian of the stolen plans that can save her people and restore freedom to the galaxy.

content.text: Apogee has a configurable form widget for easily creating forms. This reference illustrates how to create these forms.
Two examples where the form widget is used are the components

is like a non-modal dialog box. Here the programmer configures the layout of the form, including a submit button to take action. The programmer defines a handler for the save button which defines the action. There is no saved data associated with the
except the user enters data into a form rather than text editor. The configurable form format is defined by the programmer. When the user changes the value, the
appears just as if the user changed the value of a data table. When the user saves, the data is saved to an internal data table which can be accessed from the code.
In either of these components, the programmer must define the layout for the form, which is described in this document.
shows each standard form element, which you can access from the tree panel on the left.
shows each standard form layout, which you can access from the tree panel on the left.
shows how to use selectors, which control one form element based on the value of another form element.
shows how to use javascript expressions in forms. This requires the use of the
Here we show all the standard
, each defined with all type specific properties included, shown on pages defined beneath this one.
OTHER FEATURES - show how to see them!!!
Below we show a sample checkbox with all type-specific elements present.
Below we show a sample panel with all type-specific elements present. The panel element here is one of three inside the parent form.

This is basically another ConfigurableForm wrapped inside an element. The appearance of the output form looks as if we just defined to checkboxes in our top level form. However, they are wrapped in a child form. This can be seen by looking at the form value.
Here we show two forms containing list elements. The list element allows the end user to add an arbitrary number of elements to the list.
The list can be defined so there is a single element type, or in other words all elements are the same type. This must be a single configurable element. Because of this, it is often a
object. Here however we used a
The list can be defined so there are multiple element types. Again, each must be composed of a single configurable element object.

There is an important difference between the multi-element list and the single element list. In the multi-element list, the entries in the output value list contains the type of element and the element value. In the single element list, the entries in the output list are just the contained element values. This is why there are two distinct list types.
It is possible to make a multi-element list that only has a single entry, but this will be different from a single element list.
with all type-specific elements present. This is a non-interactive element.
with all type-specific elements present. This is a non-interactive element that allows you to place any raw HTML. Below we inserted a div with some text.
with all type-specific elements present. This is usually used to carry some payload value with the form.
with all type-specific elements present. This adds a specified amount of vertical space in pixels. This is a non-interactive element.
has a heading element that allows the end user to show or hide all the elements in the layout. The values of all the hidden elements are still in the form value when the layout is hidden.
with all type-specific elements present. Below we start the layout in the closed (or hidden) state. You can open it with the arrow that appears in the layout heading.
aligns the child elements horizontally. Below we put the city, state and zipcode fields in a horizontal layout.
, you can control the state of one element based on the value of another element.
Here is a simple example where we can set the state of an element to "normal" or "inactive" based on a parent value.
Here, we control the elements for the dog breed and the cat breed based on whether we have a dog or cat.
In this example, we have a selector that makes the element visible if the parent value has one of multiple values.

There is another case we should illustrate. A checkbox group has a list of output values. It is an example of a multi-value element. In this case, a selector will work if any of the selector values are selected. See the example below.
Here we allow any or multiple values to be selected in a parent will multi value selection.

Above, we specified a parent key as a simple string. Doing that you can select any key in your current panel. You can also use an array of strings, in which you are specifying a key path from the root panel.
In this example, the checkbox element labeled "Show Other Element" on a child panel controls the visibility of the text field labeled "Other Element"
The default selector action is to set the state to normal or inactive based on the value of the parent. There are other actions:
Toggle state "normal" / "inactive" - This is the default case.
Toggle state "normal" / "hidden" - With this option, the element is hidden if the parent value is not met, AND the value still appears in the form result.
Toggle state "normal" / "disabled" - With this option, the element is disabled if the parent value is not met.
It is also possible to construct a custom action.
Here you can specify a single parent OR multiple parents.
The action function you include has the following arguments:
childElement - This is a javascript object representing the child element
parentElement1 - This is a javascript object representing the first parent element.
parentElement2 - If there are multiple parents, this is a javascript object representing the second parent
... (All other specified parent elements are included too)
The main accessors you will be using from the elements are:
Below we show two examples of custom accessors, one with a single parent and one with multiple parents.
See the note below for more information on this example.
In this example, we triggered the state of the dog breed element on the pet type being "Dog". However, we had some extra work to do.
Unlike in the returned value of a form, in a selector, the value used is the value of the element whether or not the element is visible.
Here, we show or hide the
element based on whether or not the
element is checked. So here we don't only check its value we check if it is also active.
